nodes.bodyText: Could you please document why _compiler can be NULL here? This must be related to the client somehow.

Maybe this could be simplified to:
if (_compiler->getKnownObjectTable() &&
    (!_compiler->isOutOfProcessCompilation() || metadata)) // Compilation aborted early at the server

Why don't we delete those JNI references at the server if the compilation was aborted early?
This change will be removed in the next commit because the design has changed to create the KOT at the client and the server by default without exchanging messages.
Is this a bug fix?
This change is originally added for the same reason as mentioned on the above #8527 (comment). Will revert this change for the same reason.
I would like a comment explaining why this statement does not need to be done at the server.

It's not finalized. I need to trace if MCS references will be dereferenced later directly at the server. To iron out all wrinkles regarding to the scope of the change, I just disabled it at the server for now.

Why does this method need to be reimplemented? It should call the correct getIndex method, though addArrayWithConstantElements also needs to do the right thing (if the client also maintains a KOT, it may need to add the index to the bitvector represented by _arrayWithConstantElements though I am unsure).
I see a difference. In the original implementation we assume that we have VM access. However, I think that the server always holds VM access.

Yes, this method is reimplemented because of the assert that checks on the VM access in the OMR implementation.
As long as isArrayWithConstantElements() is not called at JITClient, _arrayWithConstantElements doesn’t need to be updated at the JITClient. So addArrayWithConstantElements() doesn't need to be reimplemented.
This is a new method. Does it need to be virtual?
Again, I don't know if addArrayWithConstantEelements() needs to be executed at the client as well.
Same comment as #8527 (comment).
This implementation will send two messages: one for dereferencing the JNI reference given as parameter and another to do the search through the KOT. Maybe just send a message that will do both.
These existing methods have become virtual. Why? I thought that the extensible class framework was supposed to use static inheritance.
Will clean up the virtual keywords. I guess originally, self() is not implemented in  OpenJ9 and virtual still mattered.
I guess this remains as a TODO
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -1472,6 +1472,10 @@ J9::TransformUtil::transformIndirectLoadChainAt(TR::Compilation *comp, TR::Node
 bool
 J9::TransformUtil::transformIndirectLoadChain(TR::Compilation *comp, TR::Node *node, TR::Node *baseExpression, TR::KnownObjectTable::Index baseKnownObject, TR::Node **removedNode)
    {
+#if defined(JITSERVER_SUPPORT)
+   if (comp->isOutOfProcessCompilation())

nodes.bodyText: This piece is also problematic. It is executed with VMaccess in hand to prevent GC from moving objects. However, the server will send a few messages to the client and the client does not hold VMaccess throughout this sequence of operations. Somehow we need to create a big function out of this code and execute it atomically (that is under VMaccess) at the client.

I think it can be done as a message that sends to the client the mirror (for _calleeMethod->getDeclaringClassFromFieldOrStatic()) the baseObjectIndex, the cpIndex, the fieldOffset and receives a KOT index for the fieldAddress. However, if a new entry was added the KOT at the client, the server must do the same.
Another pair of curly brackets is not needed.
Maybe an assert would be better here.
Change "it might not cause any issue" --> "and therefore it cannot cause any issues"
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -388,6 +388,12 @@ JITClientCommitVirtualGuard(const VirtualGuardInfoForCHTable *info, std::vector<
 
             {
             TR_J9VMBase *fej9 = (TR_J9VMBase *)(comp->fe());
+            // JITServer KOT:
+            // This method is called by JITClientCHTableCommit() at the client.
+            // Although accessing VM is not an issue, getIndex() could update the KOT
+            // at the client directly and the KOT at the server could be out of sync.
+            // However, JITClientCHTableCommit() is called at the end of compilation,
+            // it might not cause any issue.

nodes.bodyText: Does it make sense to have this code if we are going to crash the JVM?

I'm debating between two changes:
Either 1)
Change TR_ASSERT_FATAL() as TR_ASSERT and keep the above code as it is.
OR 2)
If (index > nextIndex), don't do the above update but only throw TR_ASSERT_FATAL().
I would prefer (2)
I see that dereferenceObjectPointerReference is only used in the JITServer specific part of getPointer. If that's the case, maybe we should make this JITServer specific.
yes, it should break
why does this need to be reimplemented? The OMR definition is exactly the same.
Will remove the redundant implementation in OpenJ9.
filterIndexList[i] = knot->getIndex(filtersList[i]);

nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -2366,7 +2379,7 @@ handleServerMessage(JITServer::ClientStream *client, TR_J9VM *fe, JITServer::Mes
          char *nextSignature = (char*)alloca(methodDescriptorLength+1);

nodes.bodyText: nextSignatureString.data() returns const char* which will not work with getStringUTF8() since it changes the content and a compilation error "invalid conversion from ‘const char*’ to ‘char*"  will throw too. Looking at other places where getStringUTF8() is called, alloca is called often. Either it could be left as it is or another alternative is to use trMemory->allocateStackMemory as https://github.com/eclipse/openj9/blob/fd96afe5f58b9125d812dcb45ae85f7376e0b7d3/runtime/compiler/control/JITClientCompilationThread.cpp#L892.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -2366,7 +2379,7 @@ handleServerMessage(JITServer::ClientStream *client, TR_J9VM *fe, JITServer::Mes
          char *nextSignature = (char*)alloca(methodDescriptorLength+1);

nodes.bodyText: ok, then alloca is fine. I was trying to avoid one round of copying by writing directly into the string buffer. It may work though if using  &mystring[0]
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -2366,7 +2379,7 @@ handleServerMessage(JITServer::ClientStream *client, TR_J9VM *fe, JITServer::Mes
          char *nextSignature = (char*)alloca(methodDescriptorLength+1);

nodes.bodyText: & nextSignatureString[0] should work. Maybe it could be done in a separate PR since alloca is used at a few places where getStringUTF8() is called  in JITClientCompilationThread.cpp on constructing the message back to the server.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -2366,7 +2379,7 @@ handleServerMessage(JITServer::ClientStream *client, TR_J9VM *fe, JITServer::Mes
          char *nextSignature = (char*)alloca(methodDescriptorLength+1);

nodes.bodyText:
We don't need to send the filtersList. These are object pointers that have no meaning at server.
However, if KOT is disabled we need a way of determining which entries have filters. Sending an array of bool will save space in this case. Thus it's better to send the array called haveFilter
The vector of filters should be replaced by a vector of bools haveFilter
Maybe other another test that recvfilterIndexList[i] is not NULL
If knot is disabled we don't have to compute getVolatileReferenceField, so let's insert this function under if (knotEnabled && knot)

If knot==NULL then this function does nothing. I would put the knot test first and only then execute
TR_OpaqueClassBlock *mutableCallsiteClass = callee->classOfMethod();
Also, the critical section for VMAccess on line 334 is not needed.
targetObjectReference is not needed
targetObjectReference is used afterwards at https://github.com/eclipse/openj9/blob/fd96afe5f58b9125d812dcb45ae85f7376e0b7d3/runtime/compiler/optimizer/J9TransformUtil.cpp#L862-L872.

I don't think it's safe for the server to ever execute this code because it deals with objects. Any object pointer may have received from the client could become stale because the client cannot hold VMaccess while sending a message to the server.
It may be the case that after all the transformations we actually don't call getIndex() from the server, but it's better to put a ASSERT_FATAL here.

I don't think it's safe for the server to ever execute this code because it deals with objects. Any object pointer may have received from the client could become stale because the client cannot hold VMaccess while sending a message to the server.

On the client side, client->write() is inside the scope of the critical section. Meanwhile, all the following methods would require access to the object pointer.  Would the other methods be a concern as well?

getIndex()
getIndexAt()
getExistingIndexAt()
getPointer()


It may be the case that after all the transformations we actually don't call getIndex() from the server, but it's better to put a ASSERT_FATAL here.

The sanity.functional test shows that KnownObjectTable_getIndexAt messages are received often on the client side. So far no KnownObjectTable_getIndex messages exchanged while running sanity.functional.
An example from StringPeepholeTest_0
JITServer Message Type Statistics:
Type# #called TypeName
...
...
#0901     149 IProfiler_searchForMethodSample
#1201      75 KnownObjectTable_getIndexAt
#1204     241 KnownObjectTable_symbolReferenceTableCreateKnownObject

StringPeepholeTest_0_PASSED

On the client side, client->write() is inside the scope of the critical section.

I missed that. If possible we have to take it out, though I am afraid we may have many transgressions like that. Fortunately, the writes are more forgiving because they block only until the kernel receives the message. In some corner cases the kernel may have a big backlog and therefore the wrote could block.

getIndexAt() and getExistingIndexAt() are safe because they don't manipulate objects.
getIndex() uses an object, which may have been moved.
getPointer() returns an object and it's safe to use, but the usage of the returned object is not safe.

I don't see getIndex called by the server in openj9. I do see some calls in OMR in VPHandlers.cpp which are bypassed. You also don't see any messages for getIndex so we may be good, but we need that ASSERT in getIndex to make sure.

though I am afraid we may have many transgressions like that

Yeah, a quick search in handleServerMessage(), I noticed many message handlings that require access to VM have client->write() inside the scope of TR::VMAccessCriticalSection().
For this PR, I will take  client->write() out of the scope of the VM access critical section for the KOT related messages first.
This is used in a single place in KnownObjectTable::getPointer(Index index). Thus, is should be marked private.

dereferenceObjectPointerReference()is used in JITClientCompilationThread.cpp. I think I should replace dereferenceObjectPointerReference() with direct messages I getPointer(). JITClientCompilationThread.cpp should be able to call getPointer() directly instead of dereferenceObjectPointerReference().

I would like an assert here that this method is not called at the server. We obtain an object pointer from the client, but it's of no use to the server, because by the time we get to use it it may have become stale. Right now the assert holds from my scanning of the code.
